instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00244: What is 820-00244? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1534: What is A1534? A1534 is a model number for a 12 inch size Macbook  from years 2015, 2016 with EMC 2746, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00045, 820-00244..
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.SPI_MOSI: What is SPI_MOSI? SPI_MOSI is a signal between the CPU or PCH and the SPI ROM bios chip that is necessary for the machine to POST and boot. If this signal line is corroded or the BIOS chip has failed then you will not get PM_SLP_S4_L and the machine will not boot. Very often this line is corroded by liquid damage. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> All power rails present, S0 state, not booting
threads.message:
Got a MacBook 12" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2017 (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) here which at first glance draws power, trackpad becomes clickable, however caps lock key does not light and it doesn't output to an external display. Noticeably it gets [I]very[/I] hot compared to a good board/laptop when left alone.

Nothing visible on the board, looks clean. All powers rails are present and <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is good. <SIGNAL>SYS_DETECT_LED</SIGNAL> is also present. <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> is 0.795V which is about the same, if a tad higher than a known good board.

I turned to looking at the SPI. When measuring with a multimeter (don't have an oscilloscope at the moment for this) on a known good board I see <SIGNAL>SPI_CLK</SIGNAL> oscillate for around 10 seconds after power input and see similar on <SIGNAL>SPI_MOSI</SIGNAL> however I don't see that on this board, it's static at 0V. Conscious I might be missing something in the 2-3 seconds after power input before the multimeter probes touch the board though.

Checked for short on <SIGNAL>SPI_CLK</SIGNAL> using diode mode, measured 1.58V vs 1.62V on a known good board.

Unsure where to look next.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> All power rails present, S0 state, not booting
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

You should check for USB activity first.
Already explained on the forum, few ways to confirm activity.
These boards are known by CPU internal problems.
Your description also points in that direction...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> All power rails present, S0 state, not booting
threads.message:
Thank you!

No USB activity, tested with an optical USB mouse, no red light. 

One interesting behaviour I did observe when I first received this laptop was that if booted with USB-C connected to another laptop (e.g. for target disk mode) the trackpad would not even become clickable when power was applied.

From reading other threads about <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> I'm aware it may be a bad CPU and this might be the case here.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> All power rails present, S0 state, not booting
threads.message:
I don't recommend to accept these boards for service even.
You can just fix a power problem and client will come back few months later; claiming warranty for non working board, caused by dead CPU.
Try to explain him that you didn't even touch the CPU before...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> All power rails present, S0 state, not booting
threads.message:
Yeah. This one actually came in from someone I know, wouldnâ€™t normally take a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> unless it was an obvious issue like a screen replacement.

Before I throw in the towel on this. Is there a good way to verify whether this is a bad CPU or something else, say bad SPI/BIOS?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> All power rails present, S0 state, not booting
threads.message:
You should see SPI activity on the first seconds only.
After that CLK and MOSI lines usually stay at 0V.
You can heat CPU and test.
Videos about reballing it available on Internet, but not worth in my opinion...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> All power rails present, S0 state, not booting
threads.message:
I see SPI activity for around about 3 seconds on this board and then the lines stay at 0V. On a known good board though I see those initial 3 seconds of activity, then activity for around about a further 5 seconds. 

Worth flashing a known good BIOS potentially? Otherwise I don't think I'm going to go any further, not worth it if it's the CPU.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> All power rails present, S0 state, not booting
threads.message: You can try BIOS, but I doubt is the problem here...
